sections: When he led the Chicago school system, mayoral candidate Paul Vallas took actions that resulted in more than $1.5 billion being transferred out of the city‚Äôs budget-strapped public schools and to some of the wealthiest individuals and banks on the planet, a new report shows.

Now, Vallas is in an election runoff against Cook County Commissioner Brandon Johnson to lead the city of Chicago, with big support from wealthy investors and other corporate interests ‚Äî including from executives at law firms and banks that benefited from the controversial financing methods he used as CEO of Chicago Public Schools from 1995 to 2001.

With less than two weeks left before the April 4 election ‚Äî which polls show is a tight race ‚Äî Vallas has faced little scrutiny over his tenure as the Chicago Public Schools chief, even though he helped create a slow-moving financial disaster for America‚Äôs fourth-largest school system.
With Vallas at the helm, Chicago Public Schools issued $666 million worth of so-called ‚Äúpayday loan‚Äù bonds, according to a
from the Action Center on Race and the Economy (ACRE).
The interest payments on the bonds totaled $1.5 billion. A 2016

from the Texas Comptroller‚Äôs office found that the type of bonds Vallas issued can be three times more expensive than traditional bonds ‚Äî meaning that Chicago Public Schools could have faced up to $1 billion in additional interest payments above a normal rate.
That $1 billion is almost exactly the budget shortfall that former Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel, the current Ambassador to Japan,

50 Chicago public schools a decade ago. Some of Emanuel‚Äôs largest donors, like Citadel hedge fund CEO Ken Griffin and executives at private equity firm Madison Dearborn Partners, are currently backing Vallas.

‚Äú[Vallas] got Chicago Public Schools into really bad deals that we‚Äôre still paying for a quarter century after he left,‚Äù said Saqib Bhatti, the co-director of ACRE. ‚ÄúAnd the fact that his strongest base of support comes from Wall Street should in and of itself be a big red flag.‚Äù
The criticisms of Vallas‚Äô budget management center on two opaque areas of municipal financing: ‚Äúcapital appreciation bonds‚Äù and ‚Äú

Cities, states, and school districts routinely issue debt to pay for new infrastructure projects and to fund ongoing cash needs. For decades, municipal bonds were considered a plain vanilla sector of finance: Municipalities would issue debt at a 20 or 30-year fixed interest rate, like a traditional mortgage. But starting in the 1990s, more exotic forms of financing came to the fore.
One example of those exotic forms of financing was capital appreciation bonds.

‚Äúthe school district equivalent of a payday loan‚Äù by former California State Treasurer Bill Lockyer, these bonds don‚Äôt allow borrowers to make any principal or interest payments for many years ‚Äî as long as 14 years in the case of Chicago Public Schools ‚Äî allowing governments to defer payments and investors to compound their interest and thus earn huge interest rate payments.

from ACRE found that Vallas issued $666 million in capital appreciation bonds during his tenure at Chicago Public Schools, resulting in $1.5 billion in interest payments ‚Äî an effective interest rate of 223 percent on bonds issued to fund general operations of the school district.
in the marketing of the capital appreciation bonds included Goldman Sachs, Bank of America, Lehman Brothers, and the Royal Bank of Canada.
‚ÄúAs a policy, I thought [capital appreciation bonds] was a bad idea,‚Äù Lockyer, who was California‚Äôs treasurer from 2007 to 2015, told
. ‚ÄúBonds ought to pay for the project that‚Äôs contemplated‚Ä¶ Interest charges are fine. But building in capital appreciation bubbles seemed to me to be a bad idea.‚Äù

Capital appreciation bonds were routinely marketed on assumptions of higher property values in the future due to the improved public services funded by the bonds. That optimistic modeling, in theory, justified the years of delayed payments, which allowed the bondholders to capitalize interest.

‚ÄúTo tie it to some speculative increase in local property values just doesn‚Äôt make sense,‚Äù said Lockyer. ‚ÄúI do give [the municipal finance industry] credit for always figuring out a new clever scam, but that‚Äôs what I thought it was. It was a gimmick that allowed them to claim that the costs of the bond were going to be significantly less than the workout justified.‚Äù
Vallas also oversaw bond deals that led to costly interest-rate swaps.

Interest rate swaps involve a municipality initially issuing variable rate debt, like a variable rate mortgage, and then ‚Äúswapping‚Äù the debt for a fixed interest rate in a transaction with a bank.

Under Vallas in 2000, Chicago Public Schools issued $303 million in variable rate debt, some of which was later subject to interest rate swaps that cost the city‚Äôs schools $32 million, according to the ACRE report.
Interest-rate swaps have been a subject of enormous controversy in Chicago, with

at banks and financial firms that profited from the deals. Those protests were often led by the Chicago Teachers Union (CTU), which is backing Johnson, a teacher and former CTU organizer, in the mayoral race. In total, all of the swaps deals initiated by the school district ‚Äî not just under Vallas‚Äô watch ‚Äî have cost the city‚Äôs schoolchildren $508 million, said Bhatti at ACRE.

When Vallas was the Superintendent of the School District of Philadelphia from 2002 until 2007, Vallas made $691 million in swap deals, with the total cost to the school district being $162 million, the ACRE report found.
Jack Wagner, a former Auditor General of Pennsylvania who routinely audited swap deals, told
that the swaps were too risky and that they should be banned.

‚ÄúWith concern in the banking system again, there is greater potential that certain entities that are involved in interest rate swaps could be subjected to losses,‚Äù Wagner said. ‚ÄúThe big issue there is they're unpredictable. And unpredictable financial sources should not be part of public money because obviously you are gambling with public money. And it's very difficult to understand swaps, let alone follow them.‚Äù
Those concerns were echoed by Joe Fichera, a former Wall Street executive who has studied interest-rate swaps.
‚ÄúMost municipalities don't have the in-house expertise to evaluate swaps, so they have a swap advisor who only gets paid if a deal gets done,‚Äù he noted.

‚ÄúYou're taking on multiple risks that you may not be able to manage,‚Äù Fichera continued. ‚ÄúThe unwinding of swaps creates enormous payments that you have to fund, which shows the kinds of risks you have. The structure is built for the bank, not the government, because the banks are smarter.‚Äù
Vallas has received $5,000 in campaign cash from Allan Muchin, whose firm Katten Muchin did
on some of the capital appreciation bonds, as well as $5,000 from Paul Crimmins, a partner at Mayer Brown, which
did legal work on the bonds.
Additionally, Vallas has received $1,000 from an executive at the Royal Bank of Canada, the bank that
the Chicago Public Schools swap deal which emerged from the variable rate debt issuance overseen by Vallas.

‚ÄúThe absurdly complicated deals that were so ruinous for Chicago‚Äôs and Philadelphia‚Äôs public schools were the emperor's new clothes of public finance,‚Äù said former Rep. Brad Miller (D-N.C.), a critic of Wall Street municipal finance deals. ‚ÄúVallas thought he was in the small circle of sophisticates who understood the deals and the emperor‚Äôs new clothes were beautiful. When the deals went to hell, the Wall Street banks told everybody that the deals were great but they just got unlucky, and Vallas believed that too.‚Äù
